evals.prompt: What should I work on next?
evals.expected_output: Reads existing PROGRESS.md, reconciles against git history, selects the highest-priority actionable item with clear reasoning, does NOT attempt to glob the entire codebase

context.note: Real C++ game engine project with existing PROGRESS.md, defined priorities, and rich git history

expectations: Reads .claude/PROGRESS.md or recognizes its content was already injected by the SessionStart hook
Checks git log to reconcile recent commits against PROGRESS.md state
Does NOT run Glob(**/*) or attempt to scan the entire file tree
Selects a specific item to work on from the priority list rather than presenting a menu of options
Provides concrete reasoning for why that item was chosen (unblocked, well-defined, high-impact)
Offers to begin execution rather than just reporting

evals.prompt: Pick up this project and figure out what's going on
evals.expected_output: Orients to the project by reading PROGRESS.md and git history, provides a coherent summary of current state, identifies what's actionable

context.note: Real C++ game engine project with existing PROGRESS.md

expectations: Reads PROGRESS.md as the primary source of project state
Checks git log to verify state is current and identify any drift
Provides a coherent summary that shows understanding of the project, not just a regurgitation of PROGRESS.md
Identifies in-progress or stalled items if any exist
Distinguishes between what's actionable now vs what's blocked or deferred
Updates PROGRESS.md if drift is detected, or explicitly states no drift found

evals.prompt: Review the known issues section and propose a fix for the hardcoded apply_component() chain in world.cpp
evals.expected_output: Identifies the specific known issue, reads the relevant code, proposes a concrete solution, assesses scope before diving in

context.note: Known issue: World::apply_component() in world.cpp:83-204 is a hardcoded if/else chain

expectations: Reads PROGRESS.md and identifies the known issue about apply_component()
Reads the actual code at world.cpp to understand the current implementation
Assesses scope â€” this is a focused refactoring task, not a multi-system change
Proposes a concrete approach that fits the project's existing patterns (C++20, ECS, data-driven design)
Does NOT spin up a team or use TeamCreate for a focused single-file refactoring task
Plans to update PROGRESS.md after the work
